I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed grants 
to the Independent State of Samoa, the Kingdom of Tonga, Tuvalu, and the Republic of Vanuatu 
for the additional financing of the Systems Strengthening for Effective Coverage of New Vaccines 
in the Pacific Project under the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility (APVAX). 1 
 
2. 
The original project adopts a regional approach to improving immunization outcomes by 
introducing three vaccines in Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu. It supports the countries in 
(i) pooling  the  procurement  of  the  human  papillomavirus  (HPV)  vaccine,  the  pneumococcal 
conjugate vaccine (PCV), and the rotavirus vaccine through the United Nations Children's Fund 
(UNICEF); (ii) strengthening primary health care and the capacity to deliver vaccination programs; 
and (iii) increasing community awareness and the population's knowledge of and attitude toward 
vaccines.  The  project  will  reduce  the  burden  and  minimize  outbreaks  related  to  vaccine-
preventable diseases, integrate immunization programs into broader health systems, and improve 
access  to  primary  health  services.  As  a  response  to  the  coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19) 
pandemic, the governments of Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu have been preparing for the 
imminent arrival of COVID-19 vaccines, and have requested additional financing from the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  further  strengthen  immunization  programs  and  prepare  for  the 
vaccine  rollout. 2  The  additional  financing  will  build  on  the  original  project  to  support  the  four 
governments in meeting their urgent needs.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had adverse impacts in all four countries (para. 7). It 
is estimated to have increased poverty by 16%–45% in the four countries in 2020, 
compared with pre-COVID-19 estimates.  Unemployment has risen and remittances 
have dropped in 2020. The pandemic has impacted women through other channels 
as well, e.g., infection risk, gender-based violence, and increased burden of care. 
All four countries have used WHO’s Vaccine Introduction Readiness Assessment 
Tool  to  complete  a  needs  assessment  that  identified  gaps  in  its  immunization 
systems. The government will address these through their National Deployment and 
Vaccination  Plans,  which  are  deemed  operationally  acceptable  for  needs 
assessments, readiness, and preparedness by the WHO. 
All  four  countries  are  prioritizing  vaccine  access  for  frontline  workers,  high-risk 
populations  with  elevated  risk  factors  (e.g.,  the  elderly,  and  those  with  co-
morbidities, disabilities, or special needs), in accordance with the values framework 
for COVID-19 vaccine allocation of WHO’s SAGE. 
All four countries have detailed an incremental medical waste management plan in 
accordance  with  WHO’s  Water,  Sanitation,  Hygiene  and  Waste  for  COVID-19 
guidelines to manage waste management from COVID-19 vaccine deployment. 
All  four  countries  have  submitted  to  ADB  a  Governor’s  letter  reaffirming  their 
commitment  to  implement  their  National  Deployment  and  Vaccination  Plans  and 
compliance with the APVAX vaccine eligibility criteria. 
All  four  governments  have  established  a  national  coordinating  committee,  or 
equivalent,  to  coordinate  the  roll  out  of  COVID-19  vaccines  and  integrating 
development partner’s contribution and support into the operational plan. ADB’s role 
is to help finance the procurement of vaccine and provide technical assistance to 
support the implementation of the National Deployment and Vaccination Plans.
